content.body: Eric Portis (he/him): it currently does, in https://github.com/annevk/orb/issues/30 I mention it as a possible fast path, but to match its processing model we'd have to track it across redirects

content.body: are there any general guidelines regarding "js property <-> HTML attribute" reflection for custom elements?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: are there any general guidelines regarding "js property <-> HTML attribute" reflection for custom elements?

content.body: for instance those interactive components whose properties change quickly (`<my-map lat=... lon=...>`)
content.formatted_body: for instance those interactive components whose properties change quickly (<my-map lat=... lon=...>)

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: for instance those interactive components whose properties change quickly (`<my-map lat=... lon=...>`)
for instance those interactive components whose properties change quickly (<my-map lat=... lon=...>)

content.body: I recall people suggesting to use attributes as the source of truth
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I recall people suggesting to use attributes as the source of truth

content.body: But that might not hold any more?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: But that might not hold any more?

content.body: Might be a good question for #web-components:matrix.org though it's not very active. There's definitely no guidelines in the standard. I'd recommend looking at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#reflect and seeing how it might be applicable for a custom element. At least if you want them to behave like built-in elements. Often that does use the attribute as a source of truth, but you could optimize around that a fair bit.

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: Just want to make sure I understand the rationale behind the LargestContentfulPaint spec. So if the image is expanded, we don't report the actual painted size, but rather we report the intrinsic size of the image

content.body: is it because we don't want web devs to game the metric?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: is it because we don't want web devs to game the metric?

content.body: annevk: “in principle ORB shouldn't really impact anyone” Half of all s load cross-origin; I’d suspect CSS background-image to have a similar breakdown. My mental model of ORB previously was: in order to adopt new image formats, lots of HTML was going to have to change, and there just wouldn’t be a way to use new image formats across origins in CSS. Big impact! Mitigated by CORP.
content.formatted_body:
annevk: “in principle ORB shouldn't really impact anyone”

Half of all <img>s load cross-origin; I’d suspect CSS background-image to have a similar breakdown. My mental model of ORB previously was: in order to adopt new image formats, lots of HTML was going to have to change, and there just wouldn’t be a way to use new image formats across origins in CSS. Big impact! Mitigated by CORP.

content.body:
> <@sefeng:mozilla.org> Noam Rosenthal: Just want to make sure I understand the rationale behind the LargestContentfulPaint spec. So if the image is expanded, we don't report the actual painted size, but rather we report the intrinsic size of the image 

That’s the basic idea. We don’t want an enormously scaled 1x1 image to be considered “largest”
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @sefeng:mozilla.org
Noam Rosenthal: Just want to make sure I understand the rationale behind the LargestContentfulPaint spec. So if the image is expanded, we don't report the actual painted size, but rather we report the intrinsic size of the image
That’s the basic idea. We don’t want an enormously scaled 1x1 image to be considered “largest”

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: I see, I start to understand the penalty factor thing..but if a scaled 1x1 image is the largest, what's wrong of reporting it..?
